<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime:
```c
void OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(uint32 msecs, struct timespec *tm)
{
    clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, tm);

    /* add the delay to the current time */
    tm->tv_sec += (time_t)(msecs / 1000);
    /* convert residue ( msecs )  to nanoseconds */
    tm->tv_nsec += (msecs % 1000) * 1000000L;

    if (tm->tv_nsec >= 1000000000L)
    {
        tm->tv_nsec -= 1000000000L;
        tm->tv_sec++;
    }
}
```

In the provided function there are no loop constructs (for/while/do-while) and only one conditional controlling expression. Other statements (function call to clock_gettime, assignments and arithmetic) are not controlling expressions and therefore do not fall under Rule 14.3. There is no do-while with an essentially Boolean constant nor any obvious infinite-loop intent that would invoke the stated exceptions. Consequently, no other fragments need investigation for Rule 14.3.
